We are back in the states for about a week following a 12 day tour through Gate1 travel. The tour was great in providing a “backbone” , meaning it hit most of the basics for what we wanted to see as first time visitors to Italy. I would recommend to people doing a tour is to read the fine details of your itinerary. We did a lot of really great things but we’re not aware for example that the part in Rome didn’t actually include a tour inside the Colloseum. In Florence we didn’t see the David Statue or go into the Uffizi museum.
This isn’t their fault, I just didn’t look closely enough or question the company ahead of time. We didn’t have the time to do those things outside of the tour. Please don’t get me wrong, it was great but if something is important to you research it ahead of time.

text:
Just got back from Italy! We did Florence, Rome, and the Cinque Terre. Wanted to share some of my experiences/favorites. We packed in carry ons and each carried 1 backpack. One our way home, we decided to check our bags as it was included in our airfare and we bought some souvenirs (including alcohol).
We went during a very hot time (temperatures averaged 97 degrees each day). We combatted this by getting out early, sight seeing in the morning, coming home after lunch, taking cold showers, and going back out in the evening. Lots of water, liquid IV, and fans!
FLORENCE - we spent 4 days in Florence!
FOOD.... Tamero Pasta Bar and Trattoria CasaLinga. AMAZING food, cheap (and good wine), and really great service. We made a reservation at CasaLinga but not at Tamero.
Everyone always recommends All'antico Vinaoi for tradition focaccia sandwiches. Not me .... walk a little further and go to Pinos Sandwiches. Shorter line, better sandwiches, cheaper, and your sandwich is made by no one other than Pino himself. He is the sweetest man and loves talking to all us tourists.
Personally, I don't think all gelato is created equally. Our favorite was Sbrino. Try to find places that serve gelato out of mental tins with lids. Those are the places that make gelato fresh (this was a tip from our air bib host).
We grabbed a drink at Loggia Roof Bar one night before dinner. Drinks were expensive and it was nothing to rave about (sure, the view is nice). If you have time to do it, go for it. But I wouldn't go out of my way to do it again.
VESPA...we used The Vespa Rent company and it was our most fun day in Florence! We had the vespa for about 7 hours and explored Tuscany. Stopped at multiple wineries, had lunch in Chianti, and got to get out of the city for an entire day. This company is amazing and provides maps for self-guided tours.
SIGHTSEE...we did the Duomo at 9AM and we were thankful for that. For starters, it wasn't 100 degrees (yet) when we walked the 400 steps to the top AND the square was empty! We got to explore and walk around without thousands of people. 100% recommend the cathedral museum. It's rich in history and amazing (plus, it has AC). Otherwise, we got lost in Florence. Walked around, went into churches, walked down less crowded streets.
ROME - we spent about 48 hours in Rome! Because we were only there for a short time, we stayed in an Air Bnb that was about 5 minutes walking from the Colosseum.
SIGHTSEE...we purchased the Rome Cards for 48 hours. These include public transportation and it includes entrance into the Colosseum (just have to reserve a time online). We went to the Colosseum at 530PM. We did the Vatican Happy Hour Tour at 7pm. It was awesome. We got a glass of prosecco, some meats and cheeses, and other snacks. Then we got to enjoy the Vatican relatively empty. We saw all the other sights - yes it was crowded, yes it was hot, but there are worst things.
FOOD...Li Rioni Pizzeria, Il Bocconcino. Both AMAZING and did not require reservations. We ate at Vecchio Roma one night. It was meh. Food was average, service was odd, and it felt very touristy and expensive. The server was annoyed we didn't pay in cash for our 80 euro bill.
CINQUE TERRE...we spent 4 days in Riomaggiore. Our airbnb was amazing and had a rooftop terrace. Beware: Riomaggiore (and all of the Cinque Terre) is hilly with lots of steps. Pack light. We purchased the Cinque Terre Cards, which includes public transport on the trains and busses (each trip on the train in between towns is 5 euro, just FYI). We went to all 5 towns and even went to La Spezia one morning.
BEACH…we went to Monterosso and got there around 10AM. We went to a beach and purchased a spot with an umbrella and two chairs. It was 38 euro and 100% worth it. We were able to come and go as we wanted for the entire day. There are free beaches but they are small and have no shade. We left around 6PM. This particular paid beach closed at 7PM. Of note, the paid spots fill up FAST…get there early.
SNORKELING…we went snorkeling with a local company in Riomaggiore. It was 45 euro and last about 3 hours. We went to three different sports and one of the tour guides pointed out specific fish, coral, and other cool facts about the Cinque Terre.
WINE TASTING…we went wine tasting at Gheme in Riomaggiore. THE BEST EXPERIENCE. It was 25 euro and we tasted 4 wines plus a sweet dessert wine that only comes from the Cinque Terre. We got an entire history of the area, of wine making, and even got food pairings with each wine. We didn’t want to leave - it was that amazing.
FOOD…we made most of our meals at home during this part of the trip. We went to the market and got pasta, tomatoes, chicken, mozzarella cheese, salami, focaccia bread, etc. We did go out to Nessun Dorma in Manrola. It’s good, very good. And the view makes it worth it. Pro tip…download the app and get in the queue before even getting there. We went to La Spezia and went to a cafe called Ciao Baby. GO THERE!!!! Literally, go to La Spezia just to go to Ciao Baby. We still talk about the food and lattes.

Happy to try and answer any questions! We were very happy with our trip.
